dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, Returnly is offering instant store credit for 65% of shoppers before they even ship a return back—does that sound like a game-changer or just another layer of risk?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Returnly is offering instant store credit for sixty five percent of shoppers before they even ship a return back-does that sound like a game-changer or just another layer of risk?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, it's risky, but the numbers are pretty compelling. They've raised $15 million from Andreessen Horowitz and even Elon Musk, so clearly investors see potential.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, it's risky, but the numbers are pretty compelling. They've raised fifteen dollars million from Andreessen Horowitz and even Elon Musk, so clearly investors see potential.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that $200 million line of credit for financing returns—that's huge. But what happens if people just… don't send stuff back? Like, they get the credit and ghost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that two hundred dollars million line of credit for financing returns-that's huge. But what happens if people just... don't send stuff back? Like, they get the credit and ghost.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It also took out a line of credit earlier this year that enables it to finance $300 million in returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, Eduardo Vilar mentioned they nudge customers over email or send printed labels, but honestly, their recourse seems limited if an item just vanishes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, Eduardo Vilar mentioned they nudge customers over email or send printed labels, but honestly, their recourse seems limited if an item just vanishes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In such an event, says Vilar, it can nudge a customer over email or try to make a return easier by sending a printed return label in the mail, for example, or scheduling the pickup of an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And yet, they claim seven in ten customers order something else before returning the first item—and spend 15% more. That's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And yet, they claim seven in ten customers order something else before returning the first item-and spend fifteen percent more. That's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nine in ten have ordered a second item before they even shipped the first unwanted item back, the company says. Theyre likely to outspend the original size of their order, too, by 23%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's smart play on impulse buying psychology. Instead of waiting for refunds, you get that instant gratification, maybe even buy a sweater on top.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's smart play on impulse buying psychology. Instead of waiting for refunds, you get that instant gratification, maybe even buy a sweater on top.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But hold on—they're not giving cash back, just store credit. So the money stays in the ecosystem. Retailers probably love that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But hold on-they're not giving cash back, just store credit. So the money stays in the ecosystem. Retailers probably love that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly offers store credit, rather than cash, in the hope that shoppers will spend the amount they are credited and then some.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and with online returns hitting $80 billion in 2017, there's a massive opportunity here. Returnly takes a cut on each transaction plus subscription fees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and with online returns hitting eighty dollars billion in twenty seventeen, there's a massive opportunity here. Returnly takes a cut on each transaction plus subscription fees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2017, over $100 billion of items that were purchased online were returned, according to the U.S. Postal Services Office of Inspector General.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, I wonder how they assess risk for each shopper. They use data from their merchant partners, but what if someone's new to shopping online?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, I wonder how they assess risk for each shopper. They use data from their merchant partners, but what if someone's new to shopping online?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In order to extend store credit the way that it does, it depends on data from its merchant network to assess a shoppers risk. This essentially means it analyzes a consumers past shopping activity at the retailers that it works with to make a decision.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's the catch—only 65% qualify right away. They must have some algorithm weighing past behavior, but it's not foolproof.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the catch-only sixty five percent qualify right away. They must have some algorithm weighing past behavior, but it's not foolproof.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And if things go wrong, they're on the hook. No disclosed figures on unreturned items, which feels… uh, a little concerning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And if things go wrong, they're on the hook. No disclosed figures on unreturned items, which feels... uh, a little concerning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company declined to disclose any figures surrounding how many items are never returned.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. But in this e-commerce boom, maybe convenience outweighs the risk. Shoppers hate waiting, retailers hate lost sales—Returnly's trying to fix both.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. But in this e-commerce boom, maybe convenience outweighs the risk. Shoppers hate waiting, retailers hate lost sales-Returnly's trying to fix both.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, and with partners like Warby Parker and Fanatics, they're already deep in the game. Let's see if that network effect pays off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, and with partners like Warby Parker and Fanatics, they're already deep in the game. Let's see if that network effect pays off.

artist_script:
HostA: So, Returnly is offering instant store credit for 65% of shoppers before they even ship a return back—does that sound like a game-changer or just another layer of risk?
HostB: Oh, it’s risky, but the numbers are pretty compelling. They’ve raised $15 million from Andreessen Horowitz and even Elon Musk, so clearly investors see potential.
HostA: Yeah, and that $200 million line of credit for financing returns—that’s huge. But what happens if people just… don’t send stuff back? Like, they get the credit and ghost.
HostB: Right, Eduardo Vilar mentioned they nudge customers over email or send printed labels, but honestly, their recourse seems limited if an item just vanishes.
HostA: And yet, they claim seven in ten customers order something else before returning the first item—and spend 15% more. That’s wild.
HostB: It’s smart play on impulse buying psychology. Instead of waiting for refunds, you get that instant gratification, maybe even buy a sweater on top.
HostA: But hold on—they’re not giving cash back, just store credit. So the money stays in the ecosystem. Retailers probably love that.
HostB: Exactly, and with online returns hitting $80 billion in 2017, there’s a massive opportunity here. Returnly takes a cut on each transaction plus subscription fees.
HostA: Still, I wonder how they assess risk for each shopper. They use data from their merchant partners, but what if someone’s new to shopping online?
HostB: That’s the catch—only 65% qualify right away. They must have some algorithm weighing past behavior, but it’s not foolproof.
HostA: And if things go wrong, they’re on the hook. No disclosed figures on unreturned items, which feels… uh, a little concerning.
HostB: For sure. But in this e-commerce boom, maybe convenience outweighs the risk. Shoppers hate waiting, retailers hate lost sales—Returnly’s trying to fix both.
HostA: True, and with partners like Warby Parker and Fanatics, they’re already deep in the game. Let’s see if that network effect pays off.
